presentation.title: Growth and Development During the Preschool Years

William R. Proffit
Dept. of Orthodontics, UNC School of Dentistry

section.title: Birth Effects, Maturation of Oral Function

pageText.p: Before viewing this program, you should have looked at the introductory programs in this series that deal with general principles in growth and the elements that control it.
This module provides details of craniofacial growth during the preschool (primary dentition) years.

Be sure you do the reading (pages 66-72 in the 5th ed or pages 60-66 in the 6th ed of Contemporary Orthodontics, and the appropriate section in your embryology text) as well as viewing this program. The text in the book is more detailed than in this computer program, and the material in the book on maturation of function will be particularly helpful in understanding it.
The learning objectives for this module are to help you understand:

ul.li: late fetal development and the effects of birth on growth
describe the changes in facial proportions from birth to early adolescence
gender differences in the rate and timing of growth
the effect on growth of low birth weight, acute and chronic illness, emotional deprivation, and malnutrition
secular trends in growth and indicate their effect on the accuracy of growth charts.

resource.label: Growth chart percentiles, birth to 3 years ﻿Fig. 3.3 in C Orthod

caption.p: You have previously seen growth charts that extend through childhood and adolescence, and have noted that there are different charts for girls and boys. One of the striking things to note is that the same chart is used for both genders in early life--there isn't any gender difference then, so we don't have to focus on that (yet).

pageText.p: The dramatic growth changes of the embryonic period of life are largely complete at 3 months in utero, and the major stages of organ development end at about 6 months. During the final trimester, rapid growth continues, with a tripling of weight between about 1000 grams at 6 months to 3000 grams at 9 months. Development of all the primary teeth and the permanent first molars starts well before birth (Table 1 below).

This chronology is just something you have to memorize, all of it for now, the last 2 columns to stay in your memory for your professional career. Your friends and patients take it for granted that you can answer their questions about baby teeth, even if you're now as far as you can get from pediatric dentistry while still practicing dentistry.

Despite the cephalocaudal pattern of growth, the head at birth still represents about 50% of the total body length, and getting it through the birth canal is potentially difficult. Two anatomic features that you can see in the photo below of a newborn make delivery easier: 1) the fontanelles of the skull allow distortion of the head, making it more tubular in shape, and 2) the mandible is quite deficient relative to the maxilla and cranium, so that the chin is "tucked in" rather than protruding.

Birth is traumatic enough to the fetus that growth temporarily stops, and usually there is a small decrease in weight between the first 7 and 10 days of post-natal life. Because calcification of bones and teeth stops for a few days, lines due to decalcification appear in both the teeth and bones that are forming at this time. The bones are not visible and remodeling would remove these lines in the near future, but enamel does not remodel, and lines in the teeth from birth trauma can be seen as they erupt later. Usually, seeing the lines requires magnification, but a difficult neonatal period can result in an area of enamel that is stained, distorted and poorly calcified. As we have noted previously, a period of severe illness later can produce similar lines on the teeth.

resource.label: Chronology of primary dentition ﻿Table 3-1 in C Orthod

page.title: Location of natal lines in teeth ﻿

pageText.p: Which part of a tooth that was developing at birth would be affected by the growth disturbance at that time? That depends on the degree of a tooth's development. As the figure below shows, the line on the maxillary incisors would be in the upper part of the crown, and it would be about the middle of the crown for mandibular incisors. On the primary canines and first molars, it would be below the cusp tips, and for primary second molars it would be near the cusp tips.

resource.label: Primary teeth on a developmental scale, showing the location of natal lines.

caption.p: The greater the amount of completion of a tooth crown at birth, the more gingivally a natal line would be formed.

page.title: Impact of low birth weight (premature birth)

pageText.p: Infants of <2500 grams birth weight, which almost always reflects premature birth, are at greater risk of problems in the immediate post-natal period, and until the late 20th century, those <1500 grams often did not survive. Now children of only 1000 grams often are saved, along with a few below that weight.

Despite their small size at birth, as the figure below shows, children judged to be small for their gestational age (SGA) and low birth weight children (premature birth) who survive make a remarkable recovery. By age 3 they usually are at about the same developmental stage as those who were normal at birth, and by age 6 they are nearly at the same height and weight as children who were normal at birth. Some professional athletes who are well above normal height and weight as adolescents and adults have a history of premature birth.

resource.label: Height and weight effects of premature birth ﻿Fig 3.4

caption.p: Note the recovery of low birth weight infants over time.

page.title: Oral Function in the Newborn: the First Breath of Life

pageText.p: The principal functions of the oral cavity are respiration, swallowing, mastication and speech. You may think it odd to see respiration in first place--but there is no doubt that it's the most important bodily function from birth to the end of life, always the number one physiologic priority. Why? Because if you can't breathe, nothing else matters.

What's the first thing you have to do when you enter the world and your umbilical cord disconnects? Take the first breath of life, using an airway that you have to open up. And to do that, you have to do three things: 1) lift up your head so that your mandible drops down, 2) bring your tongue down and forward so that it no longer contacts the posterior pharyngeal wall, and 3) expand your chest, so that air can move through your nose, across the pharynx, and into the lungs. The newborn has about 5 minutes to accomplish this; then the airway must be maintained as long as he or she lives. In those first minutes of life, the posture of the head, posture of the tongue, and posture of the mandible were established. That doesn't mean those characteristics can't be changed in the future. It does mean that any changes must be compatible with maintenance of the airway.

It's interesting and significant that a newborn infant can't breathe through the mouth, so if the nasal airway is blocked, that's a major problem. If necessary, an opening through the trachea is life-saving; fortunately, that's rarely necessary.

resource.label: Radiographic image of the first breath of life must find this in slide (or just delete the image)

caption.p: ﻿This is an image of an x-ray movie of an infant taken immediately upon delivery for imaging of the first breath, in a unique study in Scandinavia by James Bosma, an American professor of pediatrics.

pageText.p: Once an airway is established, the newborn's next priority is to obtain milk and transfer it into the gastro-intestinal system. This requires two movements: suckling (not sucking) and swallowing.

The milk ducts of mammals are surrounded by smooth muscle, which squirts milk out of the nipple when it contracts. The infant's initial goal is to stimulate its mother to release milk, and this is done with stimulatory nibbling contact with the nipple--which is correctly described as suckling. The infant places the tip of its tongue beneath the nipple, so that the milk is delivered to the top of the tongue, and transfer through the mouth requires only grooving of the tongue so that the milk slides through the mouth without further effort by the infant. Sucking isn't required and probably wouldn't work anyway.
In the first months of life, typical tongue posture is with the tongue tip pressed against the lower lip (Fig. 1). If you gently move the lip, the tongue tip will follow it.

Confusion between suckling and sucking has led to some strange thoughts about the design of bottles for feeding infants. Should an infant have to fight with an artifical nipple that would release only very small quantities of milk (Fig. 2)? No, a good mother supplies the milk generously when stimulated to do so, and a good artificial nipple should also do that.

resource.label: Infant tongue tip position Fig. 3-8 in C Orthod

caption.p: A characteristic posture of the tongue by an infant is to have the tongue tip against the lower lip. The tongue tip follows the lower lip when the lips are separated as milk is provided, putting it in the right place to receive the milk.

resource.label: An "orthodontic nipple" ﻿from lecture slide

caption.p: The theory of this device is that from the beginning, an infant should have to suck hard to get milk; otherwise he or she would develop bad habits. Since that's not at all how normal development works, it's fortunate that nipples of this type usually are discarded quickly because they increase feeding time and decrease infant satisfaction.

pageText.p: What we just described is the infantile swallow, with the lips contracted around a nipple and milk flowing through the mouth with little activity of the posterior tongue or pharyngeal musculature. The suckling reflex and the infantile swallow normally disappear during the first year of life.

As semi-solid food is added to the infant's diet, the child must use the tongue to gather up the material, position it along the middle of the tongue, and move it posteriorly. By the time the primary molars begin to erupt, a juvenile chewing pattern has developed, and a juvenile swallow pattern has been established. This is characterized by continued activity of the lips but elevation of the tongue tip, use of the mandibular elevator muscles to stabilize the position of the mandible, and increasing elevation and activity of the posterior tongue. Maturation of tongue function follows a front-to-back sequence.

The juvenile swallowing pattern gradually transitions to the adult swallow, in which tongue contact with the lips and active lip contraction are replaced with lateral movements of the tongue to gather a food bolus after chewing, placement of the tongue tip against the palate behind the incisor teeth, and a wave of tongue activity to move the along the surface of the palate into the pharynx, where it is deposited into the esophagus. This can develop as early as age 3, but has occurred in only about 50% of children by the time they enter school at age 6, and never completely develops in some individuals. The juvenile pattern is sometimes referred to as a "tongue thrust swallow". We will discuss its clinical implications (or lack of them) later as we review oral function as a factor in the development of malocclusion.

As the ability to chew develops, children move their jaw laterally, and then bring it back toward the midline as they bite down. This eventually transfers to the quite different adult chewing pattern, in which the individual opens the mouth with a largely vertical movement, and then swings the jaw laterally as they bite down. There is no evidence that the adult pattern is more effective. Instead, it seems to have to do with canine function. With primary canines present, there is little restraint to early lateral movement of the jaw; when the permanent canines erupt and come into function, it is necessary to open vertically initially, and continued vertical motion before lateral jaw movement becomes an adaptation to the new dental occlusion.

Whatever the reason for the change in jaw movement pattern, it develops at about age 12 as the permanent canines erupt, and in adults with a severe anterior open bite who never bring their canines into occlusion, the juvenile chewing pattern persists.

resource.label: Adult vs. child chewing movements ﻿Fig 3.9

caption.p: The chewing pattern for children includes lateral movement of the jaw at a small amount of opening, and wide variation in jaw movement as chewing continues, with a swing back toward the midline. The adult pattern is more organized and consistent, with lateral jaw movement on closure rather than opening.

page.title: Stages in the acquisition of speech

pageText.p: The accquisition of speech provides a clear view of the gradient from anterior to posterior in maturation of oral function. The first speech sounds-- /m/, /b/ and /p/ --come contact of the lips to shape the air stream as the child breathes out, and this occurs along with the transition from infantile to juvenile swallowing. That's why the first words a child masters are likely to be "mama" or "papa".

Somewhat later, /t/ and /d/, formed with the tongue tip against the anterior palate appear. These are followed by the sibilant /s/ and /z/ sounds, which require placing the tongue close to the but not against the palate. The last sound to be acquired is /r/, which requires precise positioning of the posterior borders of the tongue. Often this is not mastered until age 4 or 5.

Since malaligned teeth, and especially mal-related jaws, would make precise tongue positioning difficult, it is surprising that normal speech is acquired by children with severe malocclusion just as it is in those with normal occlusion. If you move the teeth or jaws orthodontically, would that create a risk of speech problems? Fortuately, no--with some minor exceptions that will be discussed in Levels II and III as we take up treatment procedures.

The brothers shown here are about the same size, but one is 6 years old and the other is 9. Can you tell which is the 9 year old? It’s the one in the blue shirt, who is slightly shorter than his brother and weighs considerably less. If you look carefully you can see that both boys seem to be missing their maxillary central incisors.

Do you think this represents normal variation? It will be very important in professional practice for you to know whether you are dealing with a child who is just small for his age, or one who is suffering from some condition that would influence the kind of treatment he should receive.

resource.label: Two brothers

caption.p: If you look carefully, you can see that both are missing maxillary anterior teeth. Is this normal variation or something beyond that?

pageText.p: The children pictured here are siblings, but only a year apart in age. The girl is shorter and less mature looking than her brother. The same question as with the last picture: given the age difference, is this normal variation, or could one or both be abnormally adanced or delayed in their growth?
How could you determine that? The best way would be to see where each of them would fit on a growth chart that shows the range of normal variation.

resource.label: Two siblings

caption.p: Do they represent normal growth?

pageText.p: The normal bell-shaped curve of variability in populations, which you are familiar with by now, expresses very well the differences in physical growth of a group of children of the same age and gender. The important question in examining any child patient is whether differences from the mean of the normal curve represent just normal variation, or whether there is an indication of abnormality in growth and development.

resource.label: Normal distribution for a population

caption.p: Knowing where an individual falls on such a distribution can be helpful in determining if they are within the range of normal.

page.title: Normal Variation: Birth Length and Weight

pageText.p: Do you recognize that this graph of variation in birth length and weight, and subsequent growth, is another version of a normal distribution? If the data were plotted as numbers of children with a given birth length or weight at any specific time, a bell-shaped curve would have been generated. You would get another normal distribution if you took any other point in time. This plot shows you the percentage of children with birth length or weight above or below a certain amount and the percentage distributions at other points in time in early life.

Normal birth weights can range from 2000 grams or about 4 ½ pounds to 4000 grams or nearly 9 pounds. Birth weights outside this range would be considered at least suggestive of abnormality. In fact, it is common today to speak in terms of birth weight instead of prematurity when discussing newborns who are at risk because of their immaturity at birth. But how was that normal range established?

resource.label: Growth curve

caption.p: This chart is really another version of a normal distribution representing growth just after birth.

pageText.p: The normal range for physical characteristics typically extends from the 3rd to the 97th percentiles, which are outside the colored area of a chart like this, which shows the 5th to the 95th percentiles.

As a general guideline, children above the 97th or below the 3rd percentile are considered possibly abnormal and in need of special investigation. It is possible that these children are simply very small or very large normals, but there is also a significant chance of an abnormality affecting growth. This is true at all stages of growth, from infancy through adolescence.

Note that the percentile lines form channels. A normal child tends to stay in the same channel. In other words, a child who starts out at the 60th percentile tends to stay there during growth. So does a child who starts out at the 20th percentile. A major change in the percentile rank suggests a deviation from the normal growth pattern and a possible abnormality.

resource.label: Growth curve

caption.p: This chart is really another version of a normal distribution representing growth just after birth, but it shows only the 5th to the 95th percentiles--so it doesn't show the potentially abnormal children below the 3rd or above the 97th percentiles.

pageText.p: Let’s look now in more detail at important factors that influence growth. Don’t forget that normal variation should go at the top of the list. In the first program in Level I, we talked about growth charts, particularly where a child is in the distribution and the significance of crossing percentile lines during growth. You might want to look again at that as we go into more detail here.
The second factor to think about now is heredity and genetic traits. ﻿delete the list, add heredity here?
FACTORS INFLUENCING GROWTH

Heredity is an obviously important factor. The boy on the left, the youngest but tallest of this group, has the tallest father, and that isn’t coincidence. Generally speaking, large children have large parents. It is not uncommon, however, to see a small or large child in a family that has a tendency toward the opposite trait.

For all human populations, there is a modest but not perfect correlation between the size of the parents and the size of the children. The correlation coefficient (r) is 0.5 or less. R², the coefficient of determination, expresses the amount of the total variation accounted for by the factor being examined. If the correlation between parent and child size is 0.5, (0.5)² = 0.25, so heredity explains not more than 25% of the variation in size.
The bottom line: heredity is an important factor in determining how tall you are, but it's far from the only thing.

resource.label: Boys with different parents

caption.p: Heredity accounts for no more that 25% of the variation in growth.

pageText.p: Another factor that must be considered in growth variations is changes in body proportions and changes in tissue systems during growth. Facial proportions, as you know, reflect the cephalocaudal gradient of growth (image 1). That’s another way of saying that generally structures close to the brain grow faster sooner and slower later than those further away.

Have you ever considered that you’re used to looking at differences in facial proportions as you evaluate how old a child is? You might well make the judgment “big for his age” based on that. How do you judge the age of these closely related boys? The difference in facial proportions is one of the things you use automatically in doing that--you have already learned to take that into account when you "size up" children.

Of course, the dentition also provides information about age. Little brother has only primary teeth, big brother has his permanent incisors but nothing beyond that. A dentist has to be able to judge dental age, and we're going to review dental age in detail later in these program--but you already know that dental age does not correlate as well with chronologic age as other biologic ages.

resource.label: Big brother / little brother

caption.p: Note the different facial proportions in the two boys, due to the normal cephalocaudal growth gradient with more growth of the lower than the upper face.

pageText.p: To a major extent, the changes in body proportions with age reflect different growth rates for different tissue systems. Classically, four major tissue systems are distinguished, and a display like this of their growth pattern is called “Scammon’s curves” after the anthropologist who first published them.

The curves show the early growth of the nervous tissues (and the neurocranium), the tremendous proliferation of lymphoid tissue early in life and its “negative growth” later, and the initially slow and then very rapid growth of sexual tissues. The adolescent growth spurt, and all the things that contribute to that, will be emphasized when we study adolescence in more detail.
You need to be able to draw these curves from memory, so look at them carefully and be sure you understand what is happening during growth of each of the tissue systems.

resource.label: Scammon’s Curves

caption.p: These curves show growth of the neural, genital, and lymphoid tissues in relation to the general somatic growth of the body.

pageText.p: The change in facial proportions with growth reflects an interaction between the neural and general body growth curves.

As you have already learned in a different context, the growth of the jaws is influenced to some degree by growth of the neurocranium, which has to grow in about the same way as the brain. We can plot curves for the maxilla and mandible like the ones Scammon plotted, making this relationship clearer and clarifying why you should expect the mandible to be underdeveloped relative to the maxilla in early childhood and why it would catch up later.

As you can see in the figure below, the maxilla almost doesn't show an adolescent growth spure. Although mandibular growth is closer to the general body curve, it too is influenced by growth of the neural structures above. It has an adolescent growth spurt, but not one as intense as the trunk and limbs. Given the gradient of growth, you shouldn't be surprised that the legs grow more than the arms.

resource.label: Maxilla and mandible added to Scammon's curves

caption.p: The curves for the growth of the jaws show that the neural growth curve influences both, with the growth curve for the maxilla closer to the neural curve than the mandible.

pageText.p: Another important factor in growth is gender. That’s more important in adolescence and adulthood than childhood, however. Boys are a little larger than girls at early ages, but at ages between 10 and 12 girls are likely to be larger, and the adult size differential isn’t there until the males have their later and more intense growth spurt.

Note the similar growth velocities for boys and girls up to puberty. In fact, the earlier sexual development in girls means that the tallest child in the 5th or 6th grade is likely to be a female. Boys end up larger because their growth continues longer.

resource.label: Change in height over time

caption.p: Note the sharp peaks near puberty – at different times – for boys and girls.

pageText.p: As you have seen in our earlier discussion of growth charts, chronic illness such as congenital heart disease or an endocrine dysfunction can lead to sustained deficiencies in growth. This usually affects both height and weight, with about the same impact on all tissue systems.
This graph shows the growth of a boy with growth hormone deficiency. Note that he was below the normal range in infancy, and that his lack of growth moved him further from the normal.

But if chronic problems are corrected, catch-up growth usually occurs. Note that when injections of human growth hormone (HGH) began at age 6 (indicated by the up arrow), this boy grew faster than normal, and almost made it to the 3rd percentile at age 14. But when HGH administration was stopped at age 14 (down arrow) growth almost stopped, and when it resumed (up arrow), there was further growth that maintained his position.
Successful repair of a congenital heart defect might have the same effect. Such a child probably would never get back to the mean, but might pull into the normal range.

resource.label: Growth curve for an individual with a growth hormone deficiency

caption.p: After injections of human growth hormone began (HGH), catch-up growth occurred.

pageText.p: Short-term illness (severe influenza leading to pneumonia, for instance) causes fluctuations in growth rates, but has little long-term impact. This is also true for chronic but still transient illness. Mononucleosis, for example, usually is followed by catch-up growth that takes a child back to the channel he was in before getting sick. One way to look at it is that absence of catch-up growth indicates a medical problem that hasn’t been corrected.

Psychologic and emotional factors also can affect growth. This graph shows the result of changing the social environment of two children who had fallen outside the normal range. Neither child had an identifiable organic cause for the growth problem. When each was removed from a very poor home environment and placed in a special boarding school where presumably emotional stress was reduced, the catch-up growth response was dramatic.
It takes severe levels of emotional distress to depress growth, but there’s no doubt this can occur. The mechanism is thought to be induction of a reversible growth hormone deficiency.

resource.label: Growth curve for two individuals with emotional trauma

caption.p: Growth increased once the psychological stress was removed.

pageText.p: The role of nutrition in growth is probably understood best from examining a chart of this type, which shows a partitioning of energy requirements. When nutrition is inadequate, the partitioning reflects physiologic priorities. Growth is, so to speak, taken off the top. If nutrition is barely adequate, generalized growth will be depressed. But if it’s adequate, better nutrition doesn’t lead to much if any increase in growth.

resource.label: Energy intake needed for growth

caption.p: In order to grow, a child must first have adequate nutrition to fulfill all other metabolic requirements.

pageText.p: Another way to consider nutrition and growth is to look at the amount of energy needed for growth as a percent of intake. An infant needs to devote a considerable proportion of the total toward growth, and this need is particularly acute for a premature infant. After infancy, the proportion of available energy devoted to growth decreases rapidly. So from a growth perspective, malnutrition at an early age would be particularly significant in decreasing or preventing growth.

resource.label: Energy intake needed for growth

caption.p: More energy is needed early in life for growth, and nutrition intake early in life is particularly important.

pageText.p: The ethnic and cultural background of an individual isn’t really a factor in growth, but it can greatly affect how growth is perceived, because the standards one is judged against can make a big difference.

For example, note the 50th percentile points for Dutch boys (blue lines) and 50th percentile points for boys from an American city (red lines), placed on this typical growth chart. At age 10, the average Dutch boy is 140 cm tall, while the American boys average 135 cm. Five cm is nearly two inches, not a trivial difference. When growth charts are used, you have to be careful about the source of the data that was used to construct them and how well the individual who is being charted fits the reference group.

resource.label: Growth curves for Dutch and American boys

caption.p: The growth chart used as reference must be appropriate for your patient to be meaningful.

pageText.p: Still another potentially important variable in growth is whether you live in the city or a rural area. This graph (image 1) shows the height of 7 year old boys in several countries, developed and underdeveloped, as of 1970. Note that the city children were consistently bigger at the same age. More recent data (image 2) shows the same trend.

The US population shows the same effect. The difference isn’t nutrition (although the vast difference for Poland may reflect a nutrition component). More services and goods—health care, sanitation, welfare—are available in the city, and that seems to overshadow any detrimental effects of city noise and pollution, except perhaps for India (and the reason for the similarity there is not known).

resource.label: Image 1, height of urban vs. rural children, 1970

caption.p: Children who live in cities have an advantage in terms of access to services that promote health and growth.

resource.label: Image 2, height of urban vs. rural children, 21st century

caption.p: The same trend holds true for more modern data – urban children have an advantage except in India.

pageText.p: Socioeconomic status (SES) and family size also can affect growth. This graph plots the height of 7 year old boys by social class and by the number of children in the family. SES is determined by the head of the household’s employment and educational status. Note that as SES declines, so does the height of the children. As the number of children in the family increases, height declines within the same SES. These differences are attributed to the amount of resources available to the individual family members.

resource.label: Height by socio-economic status and family size

caption.p: Higher SES level and fewer children in the family are associated with better growth.

pageText.p: There has been a strong trend over the past few hundred years for humans to become larger, reach an equivalent size at an earlier age, and reach developmental milestones earlier. This has occurred throughout the world, even where nutritional status didn’t change. These changes are termed the secular trend in growth.

Menarche is a dramatic developmental milestone that tends to get recorded, and so there are particularly good data for this. It’s interesting that there has been a steady decline for at least 150 years in the age of first menstruation in girls. To some extent this probably reflects earlier acquisition of a critical body mass. All other things being equal, sexual maturation in girls and menarche occur when a critical mass of about 46-48 kg (100-105 pounds) is reached. Why the faster growth to that body mass occurs now, however, isn’t totally clear. Nutrition is a part of it but apparently not the whole story.

resource.label: Age at menarche over the past 150 years

caption.p: The secular trend describes the fact that milestones of growth and development are occurring at younger ages now compared to decades ago.

pageText.p: Whatever the reason for it, the secular trend needs to be taken into account when growth charts and percentile levels are used. Growth charts often are plots of data from 30 to 50 or more years ago. Plotting typical American children of the early 21st century on growth charts from 1940s puts you pretty close to the mythical city of Lake Wobegon, where all the children are above average. People like to hear that their child is above average, which may account for the popularity of old growth charts.

resource.label: Growth chart

caption.p: To ensure accuracy, one must be sure the growth chart used as a reference is appropriately updated for the modern patient.

pageText.p: Earlier growth implies earlier physical maturation, and it is accompanied by quicker social and mental development too. Various biologic ages can be calculated, using developmental milestones, and it’s interesting to plot various indicators of a child’s physical and behavioral development on the same chart.
In this graph, various development indicators are plotted together for one particular girl. Like most people who are advanced (or a bit behind) in one characteristic, she was advanced in all of them.

On this chart, dental (the yellow line) represents dental age, calculated from the stage of dental development. Interestingly, dental age shows the poorest correlation with the other developmental scales of any of the biologic ages. A child who is advanced in everything else probably is advanced dentally too, but the dentist needs to remember that dental age doesn’t track very tightly with the other developmental ages.

resource.label: Growth and development for one individual over time

caption.p: Most milestones of growth and development follow the same pattern. Note that dental development does not follow growth very well.

pageText.p: Now let’s focus more closely on craniofacial changes in the preschool years. These cephalometric tracings of the same child at age 2 (red) and age 6 (blue) are superimposed on the back end of the cranial base, at sella turcica (the cavity in the sphenoid bone that houses the pituitary gland).

Note that during this time the brain mass increased and the brain case expanded. The cranial base lengthened, and that pushed the maxilla and midface forward. The mandible moved downward and forward, and the face grew more than the cranium—all of which you would have expected from what you already know about facial growth.

resource.label: Cephalometric superimposition of a growing child, ages 2 and 6

caption.p: The cranium has enlarged, and the maxilla and mandible have grown down and forward as expected.

pageText.p: Scammon’s growth curves (Fig. 1) show a great deal of growth of lymphoid tissue in childhood. Most of this lymphoid growth occurs in areas you can’t see, but dentists get a good look at tonsils (Fig. 2).

You’d expect the tonsils to be large in childhood and indeed they are (though usually not so large as these). Scammon’s curve predicts that they’ll normally shrink later, so large tonsils at age 6 or so often is a self-correcting condition.

resource.label: Image 1, Scammon’s curves

caption.p: Growth of lymphoid tissue peaks and then retracts.

resource.label: Image 2, view of the tonsils

caption.p: Tonsils are often enlarged near age six but then shrink.

page.title: Growth of Sex Organs and Sexual Maturation

pageText.p: As Scammon's genital growth curve shows, growth of the sex organs and sexual maturation in preschool children isn’t expected. If it occurs, which occasionally happens, something is wrong. The most likely cause is some sort of endocrine-secreting tumor, so a very sexually precocious child needs medical attention. As a dentist who treats children, you might be the first to note that your patient looked a lot more mature than one would expect at that age.

resource.label: Scammon’s curves

caption.p: There is little change in sexual maturation during the preschool years. Nothing much happens until adolescence.

page.title: Decline in Velocity of Craniofacial Growth

pageText.p: A plot of growth velocity shows that the rate of growth declines sharply from infancy to childhood. If Johnny isn’t growing as fast any more when he’s about to start to school, he’s probably perfectly normal. But notice that he’s still growing at a rate that requires new clothes and shoes every year. The rate of growth typically drops to its lowest level just before the onset of puberty and the adolescent growth.

resource.label: The original growth velocity curve, which hasn't changed in shape

caption.p: Growth in height is not obvious through much of childhood although it is still occurring, but the adolescent growth spurt is hard to overlook--and of course it's important for dentists to note it.

page.title: Cephalocaudal Gradient of Craniofacial Growth - Newborn

pageText.p: In this view of the skull of a newborn, the relative underdevelopment of the mandible is apparent. The ramus is very short. The maxilla isn’t well developed either compared to the cranium, but it’s ahead of the mandible. That’s another reflection of the cephalocaudal gradient of growth.

page.title: Cephalocaudal Gradient of Craniofacial Growth - Age 4

pageText.p: In this 4-year-old, the cranium still is large compared to the face, but the face has developed vertically as well as anteroposteriorly. The floor of the nose has descended from its earlier position just below the orbits. The maxilla and mandible have expanded laterally.
Note that the 4-year-old’s mandible has a more acute gonial angle than previously. The downward and forward growth of both jaws is evident.

page.title: Cephalocaudal Gradient of Craniofacial Growth - Age 6

pageText.p: This skull from a 6 year old child, just prior to eruption of permanent incisors, shows how the face has continued to grow faster than the cranium. The floor of the nose is now well below the orbits, and the alveolar processes of both maxilla and mandible have developed considerably.

The face still has a long way to go to catch up with the cranium, which at age 6 has reached essentially its adult size. By the time you’re six or seven, you need as large a cap as you’ll ever require, because by then brain growth is complete and the cranial vault is through expanding. In contrast, the adult mandible is twice as large as the six year old’s.

Of course it is as important to understand growth beyond age 6 as it is to understand what happens in the pre-school years. We’ll continue into that time, with emphasis on the adolescent growth spurt and its implications for orthodontic treatment, in the next program.

Before you move on to the next module, be sure you have done the reading (pages 66-72 in the 5th ed or pages 60-65 in the 6th ed of Contemporary Orthodontics) and have used the self-test to confirm your understanding of this important information.

Remember that you are being tested on the first section of Chapter 3 in Contemporary Orthodontics, the material on embryonic development of the face, as well as the content of the computer teaching program. This is pages 72-78 of the text in the 4th edition, as well as the pictures on pages 79-81. Read this carefully. It’s not covered in any of the computer teaching programs.

page.title: Question 1
page.pageText: The embryonic source of almost all the facial tissues is:

correctResponse.p: That’s correct. In the formation of the face almost all the tissue, including muscle and bone that elsewhere is derived from mesoderm, is of ectodermal origin.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s incorrect. In the formation of the face almost all the tissue, including muscle and bone that elsewhere is derived from mesoderm, is of ectodermal origin.

pageText.p: Hemifacial microsomia and related congenital syndromes arise at which of the stages of craniofacial development?

choices.choice: germ layer formation and initial organization of structures
origin, migration and interaction of cell populations

correctResponse.p: That’s right. Hemifacial microsomia is an example of a problem arising early in development from loss of neural crest cells before they migrate into the developing fact. Thalidomide and isotretnoin (Accutane) are drugs that create malformations by this mechanism.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. Hemifacial microsomia is an example of a problem arising early in embryologic development from loss of neural crest cells before they migrate into the developing face, so it arises at the stage of origin, migration and interaction of cell populations. Thalidomide and isotretenoin (Accutane) are drugs that create malformations by this mechanism.

pageText.p: Cleft lip and palate arise at which of the stages of craniofacial development?

choices.choice: germ layer formation and initial organization of structures
origin, migration and interaction of cell populations

correctResponse.p: That’s right. Cleft lip and palate arise after the cell populations are in place, at the stage in the second month of embryonic life when organ systems are being formed.

incorrectResponse.p: No, you’re wrong. Cleft lip and palate arise after the cell populations are in place, at the stage in the second month of embryonic life when organ systems are being formed.

pageText.p: The upper lip in an adult is derived from which of the facial processes?

choices.choice: median nasal, lateral nasal and maxillary

correctResponse.p: That’s right. The upper lip is derived from the median nasal and maxillary processes. Although failure of fusion between the median and lateral nasal processes results in a cleft lip, the lateral nasal process forms the outer parts of the nose and contributes little or nothing to the ultimate upper lip.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. The upper lip is derived from the median nasal and maxillary processes. Although failure of fusion between the median and lateral nasal processes results in a cleft lip, the lateral nasal process forms the outer parts of the nose and contributes little or nothing to the ultimate upper lip. The correct answer is (3) median nasal and maxillary.

pageText.p: Crouzon’s syndrome and the other malformations due to early closure of craniofacial sutures arise at which of the stages of craniofacial development?

choices.choice: germ layer formation and initial organization of structures
origin, migration and interaction of cell populations

correctResponse.p: That’s right. The characteristic hypertelorism and midface deficiency of Crouzon’s syndrome are due to prenatal fusion of the superior and posterior sutures of the maxilla, along the wall of the orbit. This occurs in fetal life, during the final differentiation of tissues, considerably later than the embryologic origin of clefts and related problems.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. The characteristic hypertelorism and midface deficiency of Crouzon’s syndrome are due to prenatal fusion of the superior and posterior sutures of the maxilla, along the wall of the orbit. This occurs in fetal life, during the final differentiation of tissues, considerably later than the embryologic origin of clefts and related problems.

pageText.p: (A) In normal human infants, the mandible is prominent at birth because (B) like all the structures of the head and face, a high percentage of mandibular growth is completed before birth.

choices.choice: A true, B true, A and B related
A true, B true, A and B not related

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, both statements are false. Human newborns have an underdeveloped mandible relative to the rest of the head and face, for which their mothers should be grateful because this facilitates the head’s passage through the birth canal. The mandible grows more than other facial structures in postnatal life and eventually catches up.

incorrectResponse.p: That’s wrong. Both statements are false. Human newborns have an underdeveloped mandible relative to the rest of the head and face, for which their mothers should be grateful because this facilitates the head’s passage through the birth canal. The mandible grows more than other facial structures in postnatal life and eventually catches up.

pageText.p: At what degree of deviation from the normal height-weight standards is special investigation of a child’s status indicated?

correctResponse.p: That’s right, the general guideline is that children who are below the 3rd or above the 97th percentile should be examined carefully to be sure they represent only normal variation rather than some abnormal condition. Such a child would plot outside the colored area of a chart like the one shown here.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. The general guideline is that a child who is below the 3rd or above the 97th percentile should be examined carefully to be sure they represent only normal variation rather than some abnormal condition. Such a child would plot outside the colored area of a chart like the one shown here.

pageText.p: How well can you predict the size a child will attain from examining her parents?

correctResponse.p: That’s right, there is a correlation between the size of parents and their children, but genetic / hereditary factors explain only about 25% of the variation, so 25% accuracy is about all you could hope for.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s incorrect. There is a correlation between the size of parents and their children, so knowing the size of parents has some predictive value. But genetic / hereditary factors explain only about 25% of the variation, so 25% accuracy is about all you could hope for.

pageText.p:
Compared to an eight-year-old, a normal four-year-old child has a:
(1) relatively larger cranium
(2) relatively longer lower face
(3) more prominent mandible.

correctResponse.p: That’s right, compared to an eight-year-old, the four year old has a relatively larger cranium, but the face is shorter and the mandible less prominent, because the face grows faster than the cranium between ages four and eight.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. Compared to an eight-year-old, the four year old has a relatively larger cranium, but the face is shorter and the mandible less prominent, because the face grows faster than the cranium between ages four and eight.

pageText.p: (A) The growth curve for the mandible follows the neural growth curve because (B) all the facial structures are close enough to the brain to be influenced by its growth curve.

choices.choice: A true, B true, A and B related
A true, B true, A and B not related

correctResponse.p: That’s correct. The mandible doesn’t follow the neural growth curve, so the first statement is false, but it’s true that the facial structures are close enough to the brain to be influenced by its growth curve. In fact, the growth curves for the maxilla and mandible fall in between the neural and general body curves.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. The mandible doesn’t follow the neural growth curve, so the first statement if false, but it’s true that the facial structures are close enough to the brain to be influenced by its growth curve. In fact, the growth curves for the maxilla and mandible fall in between. The correct answer is (4) A false, B true.

pageText.p: At age 12, girls are typically:

choices.choice: smaller and less developed than boys
smaller but more developed than boys
larger but less developed than boys
larger and more developed than boys

correctResponse.p: That’s right. Girls reach their adolescent growth spurt earlier than boys, and at age 12 they’re typically both bigger and more developed. The males end up bigger because they continue growing for a longer time.

incorrectResponse.p: That’s wrong. Girls reach their adolescent growth spurt earlier than boys, and at age 12 they’re typically both bigger and more developed. The males catch up and ultimately are bigger because they continue growing for a longer time.

pageText.p: Complete recovery from low birth weight, so that the individual ends up close to the mean for the population in height and weight as an adult, is:

choices.choice: often happens but frequently does not
quite unlikely, growth deficit usually persists

correctResponse.p: That’s correct. In the absence of other problems, it’s quite likely that a child who was born prematurely and therefore has a low birth weight will ultimately completely catch up with his or her peers.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. In the absence of other problems, it’s quite likely that a child who was born prematurely and therefore has a low birth weight will ultimately completely catch up with his or her peers.

pageText.p: Complete recovery from a growth deficit caused by chronic illness such as growth hormone deficiency, so that the individual ends up close to the mean for the population in height and weight as an adult, is:

choices.choice: often happens but frequently does not
quite unlikely, growth deficit usually persists

correctResponse.p: That’s right. A child who is successfully treated for a chronic growth-inhibiting condition usually moves closer to the growth norms, but the growth deficit usually persists. The longer the problem was present, the less the chance that the child will achieve normal height and weight.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s incorrect. A child who is successfully treated for a chronic growth-inhibiting condition usually moves close to the growth norms, but the growth deficit usually persists. It’s quite unlikely that he or she will be at the median for the population, and the longer the problem was present, the less the chance that the child will achieve normal height and weight.

pageText.p: (A) Severe acute illness affects a child’s growth status only temporarily because (B) rapid catch-up growth usually occurs after the illness.

choices.choice: A true, B true, A and B related
A true, B true, A and B not related

correctResponse.p: That’s right, both statements are true and they’re related. Even though growth stops during the acute illness, a subsequent period of rapid catch-up growth usually brings the child back to his or her previous status.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. Both statements are true, and they’re related. Even though growth stops during the acute illness, a subsequent period of rapid catch-up growth usually brings the child back to his or her previous status.

pageText.p: Severe growth inhibition due to a highly stressful social environment is:

choices.choice: never happens directly, effect secondary to malnutrition

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, psychologic and emotional factors can affect growth, but severe growth inhibition (fortunately) is rare even though it is possible. Subtle effects may be relatively common.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. Psychologic and emotional factors can affect growth, but severe growth inhibition (fortunately) is rare even though it is possible. Subtle effects may be relatively common.

pageText.p: (A) Chronic malnutrition does not affect growth in the same way as chronic illness because (B) the energy available to an individual is preferentially directed toward growth.

choices.choice: A true, B true, A and B related
A true, B true, A and B not relanted

correctResponse.p: That’s right, both statements are false. Chronic malnutrition affects growth remarkably similarly to chronic illness. Energy is available for growth only after the organism’s other needs for survival have been met.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s incorrect. Both statements are false. Chronic malnutrition affects growth remarkably similarly to chronic illness. Energy is available for growth only after the organism’s other needs for survival have been met.

pageText.p:
Influences on the ultimate height of an individual include:
(1) racial/ethnic origin
(2) rural vs urban setting
(3) number of children in the family

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, not only racial/ethnic origin but also rural vs urban setting and number of children in the family are influences on an individual’s ultimate height. Urban children and members of smaller families tend to be bigger, perhaps because more resources are available to them.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong, all three of these factors can affect growth. Not only racial/ethnic origin but also rural vs urban setting and number of children in the family are influences on the individual’s ultimate height. Urban children and members of smaller families tend to be bigger, perhaps because more resources are available to them.

pageText.p: The term “secular trend” in growth and development refers to:

choices.choice: the world-wide trend toward earlier development
the unpredictability of changes over time
the increase in the age at menarche observed in many countries
the way growth charts quickly go out of date

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, a secular trend is one that is related strongly to time. In growth and development, there has been a strong world-wide trend toward earlier development. Earlier (not later) sexual maturation is only one example of this.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. A secular trend is any of a number of changes that are related strongly to time. In growth and development, there has been a strong world-wide trend toward earlier development. Earlier (not later) sexual maturation is only one example of this.

pageText.p: An average child from your practice in some future year, whose growth is plotted on a growth chart based on 1965 data, is likely to appear:

choices.choice: no way to predict because of the secular trend

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, the average child now is bigger at the same age than the average child of the 1960s and this trend toward faster growth and development seems to be continuing, so the old growth chart would make an average child look advanced. Most people are pleased to be told their child is above average, which perhaps accounts for the popularity of old growth charts.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. The average child now is bigger than the average child of 50 years ago and this trend toward faster growth and development seems to be continuing, so the old growth chart would make an average child look advanced. Most people are pleased to be told their child is above average, which perhaps accounts for the popularity of old growth charts.

pageText.p: Which of the following is not typical of physical growth in the preschool years?

choices.choice: lymphoid tissue is beginning to shrink

correctResponse.p: That’s correct, lymphoid tissue tends to grow very rapidly during the preschool years. It doesn’t begin to shrink until sexual development starts at the beginning of adolescence.

incorrectResponse.p: No, that’s wrong. During the preschool years, neural and cranial growth is nearly completed, and there is very slow sexual development. But lymphoid tissue tends to grow very rapidly. It doesn’t begin to shrink until sexual development starts at the beginning of adolescence.
